utterances.sentences: I - I'm-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --exactly.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: No, I'm saying it - I'm saying it right now. We've - I've always said this on your show, Tucker, we agree on this. The U.S. has every right to secure its border.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: I just think we don't agree on this strategy. You want to keep spending billions of - of dollars in militarizing the border. You want to keep spending billions of dollars in trying to seal the border. I say let's spend more money on the root causes of immigration. Let's spend more money on trying to prepare--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --for the humanitarian crisis we're facing for the new reasons why people are migrating-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well I'm - I'm - wait, wait, wait, hold on. You - this - this is - hold on, this is - this is--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --like climate change instead of just focusing on border security like this is the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --this is (ph) BS.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --the magic solution.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I can't keep - I can't keep up here. Very quickly, let's just isolate one of the claims you just made that we need to spend more money (ph)--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --in the root causes. So, the root cause of what I think is imminent immigration from Venezuela here is the collapse of the Venezuelan government. What should we do - that's the root cause. What should we do about that exactly, seriously? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, I think that, you know, a - important contingent of Venezuelans have come here legally with visas with--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. But please don't dodge the question.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --you know--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You said we need to - we need to--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: No, but--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --address the root problem. That's the root problem. The Ven--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Right. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --the Maduro government is collapsing.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Well finding a peaceful solution to the conflict in--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, what should we do about it?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --Venezuela is a good - good first step.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What would that be? What would be the peace--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Today, President Maduro has said--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. But what can we do about it? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --well negotiations. I know he has been manipulating and abusing negotiations and dialog for over the past five years and he's now (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Should we send troops there?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --I - I don't think a military intervention with a history of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, you don't have an answer. There's no answer.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --no, no, look, but - but look at the history of military interventions--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I mean the U.S. can't fix Venezuela, I mean come on.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --in the U.S. You're just talking about Central America right now and about Nicaragua and other countries-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But we're making the same point.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --where a lot of - most of the refugees are coming from and that has to do (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're making the same point.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --in large parts with - with the history of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. It's America's fault. OK, so--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --of U.S. intervention in - in Central America.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --so you're - you're kind of - you're kind of undercutting-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: You have to recognize that, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --you're undercutting on argument. You're saying the U.S. has to get involved in these Latin countries in order to prevent--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Not militarily, of course, not.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it is - well not militarily.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: I didn't say (ph) militarily.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We need to send them more money. We send them a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Not at this point. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And it hasn't helped at all. OK. So, we need to send them more money and then they'll stop coming here? Are you making that argument? How much will we have to send to keep them stop coming here?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: No, in the case - the - the reasons why people are feeling from Venezuela are different from the reasons they're fleeing from--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, what do you do about this root cause?

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --countries in Central America.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why not just build a freaking wall--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: But saying - if you want to talk about Venezuela--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and call it a day.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --if you want to talk about Venezuela where, by the way, diplomats - U.S. American diplomats are today remaining behind despite grave danger without being paid. And that's, I think, truly heroic. But if you want to talk about Venezuela and the reasons why people are fleeing, maybe finding a peaceful solution to the conflict there would help. And having the U.S. which has played--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --I think the Trump Administration a very positive role in this sense--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --could - could, you know, be--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Whatever! It's not our country.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --be part of that solution.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: This is our country. And the prospect of being invaded by desperate people--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Yes, but we - we live in an international (ph) world whether we like it or not.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --no, I don't know. I - and I actually--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: You can't remain isolated.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --don't like the idea that you could be invaded, and you're not allowed to do anything about it. That seems like a kind of baseline--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: And look - look how well multilateralism has--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --request.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --has worked in the case of Venezuela. All of the world is backing--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --the U.S. on this. Maybe the Trump Administration will now learn, hopefully, that it works when you, you know, you--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Let me - let me just bottom-line it. I'll--

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: --your working with partners will be good (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I'll get the last word for once. If the rest of the world is backing it, it's got to be bad for us. I think that's a - that's a kind of fair assumption.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think so. Enrique, great to see you.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: That's - that's where we disagree the most.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You got the last word. Good job.

utterances.speaker: ACEVEDO
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Well after a very brief period of regret, almost instantaneous, the press is renewing its offensive against those dangerous Catholic school children in Kentucky who must be suppressed. We'll show you evidence, after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well the media war against the menacing children of Covington Catholic at Kentucky continues tonight. The brief moment of media regret has been forgotten entirely. Yesterday, the TODAY show, questioned especially terrifying Covington student Nick Sandmann, they suggested that he had attacked a grown man, Nathan Phillips by not bowing down or running away, when Phillips approached him as he should have.

utterances.speaker: SAVANNAH CLARK GUTHRIE, CO-ANCHOR OF TODAY, NBC NEWS
utterances.sentences: There's something aggressive about standing there, standing your ground.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's just - don't just stand there, it's aggressive. Well today, that same anchor over at NBC interviewed Phillips. He's the Native American Elder you've been hearing so much about. And that anchor had no shortage of material to ask Mr. Phillips about his numerous false statements, which he has made on tape recently, his misrepresentation of his military record, or this interview in which Phillips describes a group of passive stationary children as a "Lynch mob." Watch.

utterances.speaker: NATHAN PHILLIPS, OMAHA NATION ELDER AND ACTIVIST
utterances.sentences: The same faces that were on the crowds of those youth at - at on - at the D.C. was the same faces of - of the youth that were surrounding the young Black woman who was trying to get an education. And the scorns and the scowls that were on the pictures there, the same pictures of when you see pictures of lynchings, the same faces on the - on the folks that were doing the lynchings, that's what these young people's faces looked like.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: This is becoming a society that speaks almost exclusively in cliches, and that's a - that's a sign of decline. In the case of the tape you just say, that was false. It was totally misleading and slanderous. And lies like that will hurt these kids for life. So, maybe Phillips could have been asked about that, but no. Instead, he got the softest interview network has - television has done since Princess Die. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: GUTHRIE
utterances.sentences: He does wish that he had walked away. Was that enough for you, or do you think he should have apologized?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: Me. I'd be, like, way down on the list of his people he needs to apologize to.

utterances.speaker: GUTHRIE
utterances.sentences: Did you hear anyone say, "Build that wall?" It isn't audible on the video clips, I think, that are out there, but did you hear that?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: You know, I did hear that. And I have seen some out there on the - on the internets where there's - you can hear them saying, "Build that wall."

utterances.speaker: GUTHRIE
utterances.sentences: And how did you feel in that moment? Did you, yourself, feel threatened?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Joe Concha writes about Media for The Hill, and joins us tonight. Joe, I know the anchor you just saw who's very - actually a very nice person, I would say, I don't think a mean person, but that's not journalism. It's nauseating, actually. And why would - didn't some producers say, "I'm sorry. You have to do a real interview at some point. This is a news story. Do a news interview." Why weren't they willing to do that?

utterances.speaker: JOE CONCHA, THE HILL MEDIA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Or Tucker, after the fact when Nathan Phillips said, "I saw videos where you could hear the students chanting Build that Wall!" NBC News needs to go back and say A, review all the tapes, and then, B, once they come to the conclusion that every other news organization has come to, which is no one has heard anyone chant "Build that Wall!" they have to tag it out, and you know what a tag is, after the reports say, NBC News could not verify what Nathan Phillips was saying. And you're right about that being a softball interview. He was - he was asked by Savannah Guthrie in the beginning, "How are you doing? How are you feeling?" And how can you ask, if you're Savannah Guthrie, how do you not have the self-awareness to just know that if you ask the 15-year-old kid that was exonerated by all those videos if he should apologize, how do you not ask Nathan Phillips that same question? That's all people at home want. Just some--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CONCHA
utterances.sentences: --consistency. You ask him to apologize. You have - have to ask Nathan Phillips to apologize as well.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You know, Conservatives spend a lot of time complaining about how tough the media are on Trump and his supporters, OK. I don't mind it when journalists are tough. We almost never point out the real crime, which is, they go soft on everybody else. Everything is cheesecloth in front of the lens, soft focus. I mean it's disgusting actually.

utterances.speaker: CONCHA
utterances.sentences: Yes, the soft part, you're - you're right about that. Read The New York Times today where they did a full feature on the Black Israel rights - Israel right - Israel rights, excuse me, where at - at no point do they reference the homophobic slurs that this group traffics in, the racist slurs that they traffic in, then juxtapose this with Dan Levin, New York Times Reporter tweeted out earlier, and I - I had the producers do a full screen quote on this, just so everybody could read along at home because it's remarkable. "I'm a New York Times reporter writing about #exposechristianschools. Are you in your 20s or younger who went to a Christian school? I'd like to hear about your experience and its impact on your life." Gee and (ph) do you think this reporter's going in with a nefarious agenda? And, by the way, you could paint any public institution if you solicit enough people--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CONCHA
utterances.sentences: --as a horrible place whether it be a public school, private school, Hebrew school, Muslim school. And this reporter is going to then present a story that's going to be seen as objective by his editors to readers who won't know better to take down the Catholic institution, #exposechristianschools. This is - I don't use this word very often, Tucker, because I don't like the whole hyperbole cable news thing, this is disgusting for a reporter--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: CONCHA
utterances.sentences: --to do this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I agree with that. Joe Concha, thank you very much for that.

utterances.speaker: CONCHA
utterances.sentences: All right, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You don't want to be a young man in America right now. And that is, again, is not hyperbole. Look at the numbers. Their economic prospects are worse. The education system is built to favor girls. And now, their entire sex is routinely attacked with smears about toxic masculinity or their evil smiles. How do parents respond to this? Let's say you have a son. What do you do exactly? Melissa Braunstein has thought a lot about this. She's a Senior Contributor to The Federalist, which is excellent, and she joins us tonight. So, this is a real question for those of us who have boys. How do you respond to a culture that hates them for being boys?

utterances.speaker: MELISSA LANGSAM BRAUNSTEIN, THE FEDERALIST SENIOR CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well that's something I'm - I'm starting to figure out. We have three girls, and we had our first son last fall. So, we're new to the whole boy thing. But it is - it is a huge question on my mind at this point because it became very apparent to me, last year, when I was pregnant and starting to think about these things that our culture is sending very different messages about being a girl in America and being a boy.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Where, as my daughters are constantly told they can be whatever they want to be and whoever they want to be, which I applaud--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Me too.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --I feel like the - the messages being sent toward my son are much more negative and narrow, and that he's being already warned, even at the size of a doll, that toxic masculinity is an issue. And I - to me that this is so ridiculous that we're pigeonholing boys into this category, everyone is terrible, and girls, we somehow - somehow, we're able to recognize there's - everyone's an individual--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But the effects are--

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --and the others are (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --failure, suicide--

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --drug addiction.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I mean and you can see it in the numbers. So, this is - it's - it's actually a crisis, for real.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, what do you do?

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well I think it's important, in terms of boys, making sure they have positive male role models--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --especially fathers, to have engaged and involved fathers as much as possible. If not, for whatever reason, to have people in the community that the boys can look up to, who are demonstrating positive leadership role model behaviors, whether it's being a scholar or a teacher or warrior--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --or any other of an array of things just to make sure the boys know there are wonderful ways to be a man, masculinity is not toxic, and that there's no reason to be ashamed or to feel sidelined.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The way you are is not a crime.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It might be worth repeating that to them. Good luck! Good luck raising your boy. He's lucky to have three sisters.

utterances.speaker: BRAUNSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Well Big Tech is becoming much more like Big Brother every day, China leading the way on that. Mark Steyn has thought this through. What will our country look like a 100 years from now, or maybe two years from now? He joins us after the break.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: TECH TYRANNY.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well modern technology is supposed to make our lives easier and freer. That's the promise. Increasingly though, some suspect that the gadgets we use every day are becoming tools to control us. A recent piece in Wired magazine, and it's worth reading, and it captures this phenomenon and the threat (ph) of it. It describes what's happening in China right now under its social rating system. Here's the lead of the piece. "A friend of mine, who runs a large television company in the car-mad city of Los Angeles, recently noticed that his intern, an aspiring filmmaker from the People's Republic of China, was walking to work. When he offered to arrange a swifter mode of transportation, she declined. He asked why, she explained that she "needed the steps" on her Fitbit to sign in to her social media accounts. If she fell below the right number of steps, it would lower her health and fitness rating, and that's part of her social rating, which is monitored by the Government of China. A low social rating could prevent her from working or traveling abroad." That's what's going on there. Author and Columnist, Mark Steyn joins us tonight. So Mark, I'm not paranoid by temperament. But - but it seems like this regi - this regimen in the world's most populous country might be getting more attention than it is in this country. It's getting no attention.

utterances.speaker: MARK STEYN, STEYNONLINE.COM
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And that makes me nervous. Why do you think our press is ignoring this?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Well I - I think you're right to be nervous. Tocqueville actually, two centuries ago, Alexis de Tocqueville in Democracy in America asked this question. He said that theoretically, in Europe, the King wielded absolute power. But in practice, he couldn't actually do much about it because--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --he was in his palace hundreds of miles away, and you're in your hovel. And once every half decade, a pantalooned emissary might show up in your dooryard and give you a hard time about something. But for the rest of the time, you got on with your life undisturbed by his absolute power.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: And Tocqueville wondered what would happen if the Administrative State evolved to the point where it could control every aspect of social life and individual existence. And with three companies now, Amazon, Google YouTube, and Facebook, we're now seeing dangerous signs in China, in Europe, and in the United States of the alliance between big government and Big Tech. And Big Government plus Big Tech does equal Big Brother 24/7.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, what are the ways in - I mean presumably, like everything, these things start in a subtle way. So, the - the Fitbit example from the People's Republic of China doesn't seem at first blush, authoritarian. They're not forcing to believe anything (ph).

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They just want you just, you know, be fit because like cardio health--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --is really important. And if you want health insurance--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --you're going to get your steps. But that is--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --authoritarian.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Yes, it - yes, it is. And I think it's worth thinking about how quickly our thinking has evolved on this. If you remember, after 9/11, the Left made a huge fuss because President Bush was supposedly monitoring what library books people checked out of public libraries.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right. Right, I remember that.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Now, not a lot of people - not a lot of people actually check out books at public libraries. The Public Library System is dying. But as we objected to that, just 15 years ago, we're now completely OK with the fact that everybody wears an electronic ankle bracelet that lets people know where you are on the planet any hour of the day. That's a thing called, what we used to call, the telephone. A telephone now tracks your movements. And the - and the three companies that - that - that - that are the principal repositories of that information, for example, Amazon's deal with the CIA and the NSA here, Google's design of a kind of knowledge - access to knowledge compliant with the Chinese Politburo, in Europe, Monsieur Macron and Angela Merkel meeting with Facebook to decide how the bounds of free speech that Facebook will permit during election seasons, the - the Left and - and what's left of the non-internet media are absolutely silent on this and the threat it represents.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, when Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York says, in effect, if you don't agree with my politics, if you dare to oppose me, you can't do business in the state or you can't bank. It's what he's done to the NRA in the State of New York.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why wouldn't that become universal?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that's right. I mean we - we actually talk about Amazon, for example, just started off as a - as an online book competitor with Borders. It then put Borders out of business, and it's now becoming essentially a retail outlet, a one-stop retail outlet for the world. We talked a couple of weeks ago about the way that these companies are now actually developing an alternative to money. So, people think, "Oh, it seems - it seems ostensibly quite sensible to say, oh let's give up check books and let's give up paper money." But essentially, what that means is that every time you spend $4.75 on a cup of coffee at Starbucks that the state actually knows where you are--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --and that transaction. And that's leading us. I mean we now live in an age where Big Brother is following you. And, unlike George Orwell, we have largely accepted that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why were the Luddites wrong? And that'll be the topic next week when you come back. I'm not sure they were.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Mark Steyn, great to see you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Thanks a lot, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, last year, criminal justice policies changed dramatically in the City of Philadelphia after a new D.A. Larry Krasner took office. He was backed by George Soros. And Krasner massively scaled back law enforcement in the city. Prosecutors stopped prosecuting numerous crimes. They stopped seeking cash bail for even some felonies. They deliberately impose shorter prison sentences. Dozens of prosecutors were fired. So, what happened? Cause and effect? Well the most murders in a decade. We spoke recently with the President of Philadelphia's Fraternal Order of Police, John McNesby, and here's what he told us.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Mr. McNesby, thank you very much for joining us tonight. So, Philadelphia--

utterances.speaker: JOHN MCNESBY, PHILADELPHIA FRATERNAL ORDER OF POLICE PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --got a new District Attorney, as we just said, with the backing of George Soros. He made changes to the way that crimes were prosecuted in Philadelphia. What was the result?

utterances.speaker: MCNESBY
utterances.sentences: Well the result is that, I said at this time last year that crime would be through the roof. Excuse me. Over the last year, there's been 6,500 less cases brought before the Criminal Justice Center here. Crime is up. 4,000 felons are on the streets running the City of Philadelphia. And it's, you know, everybody's pointing the fingers to police officers, to the Police Commissioner. And we're - fact of the matter is we're out doing the job. He's decimated the Philadelphia District Attorney's office. He has a great disdain and dislike for law enforcement. He let go many prosecutors his first week in, 31, to be exact. There's a 30 percent turnover rate. So, all that while we're out there trying to protect the community.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, an ideologue comes in with Left-wing backing and guts the criminal justice system. Crime rises, and then the police get blamed for it? Is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: MCNESBY
utterances.sentences: Well everybody's pointing the fingers at "What's the police going to do? What's the police commissioner going to do?" Fact of the matter is we have officers out there arresting people on a daily basis, and they're walking out the back of police stations. He's cutting deals with defense attorneys. He's cutting deals - one, just a couple of weeks back, where a - a felon who had 14 priors, 14 priors, goes into a store, shoots the owner with an AK-47, and he cuts a deal without the victim knowing for 3.5 to 10 years. I mean that's - that's insane. And that's not happening once or twice. It's happening so many times now that the Judges in the City of Philadelphia are getting wind of it, and they're - they're starting to check and double- check and triple-check these deals.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What - what's the motive here? I mean to the extent we know, why would a District Attorney want to let felons - felons out of prison and give lighter sentences to people who commit violent gun crime? Why?

utterances.speaker: MCNESBY
utterances.sentences: Well he's actually - he was a - previously he was a Defense Attorney. He filed before taking office. And I think he's turned the District Attorney's Office into the Defender Association. I forget - I think he forgot the oath that he had taken to uphold the law and enforce the law in the city. But he was prior a defense attorney, and sued the City and the Philadelphia Police Department over 70 times during - during his tenure. On top of that, he has now a Do Not Call list, where he has not one, two, three, 10 officers. In fact he has (ph) few hundred officers on this list, and I don't know how or he's not explaining how officers get on that list, get off the list, what's the just cause of being put on the list. He's running his own show here, and it's like a Carnival act.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What - what's the effect on poor neighborhoods in the city?

utterances.speaker: MCNESBY
utterances.sentences: Well it's not - I think everybody's catching wind now that it's not just, you know, it's not - it's - it's not just the victims of these crimes, although that's very, very important, because he's not letting them know anything. Now, it's the community that are seeing people run rampant in their neighborhoods, shoot at each other, whether it's poor, whether it's affluent, it really doesn't matter. It's - it's across the City of Philadelphia. They're not picking and choosing. These aren't people that you let out and - and we're all for, you know, reform, and--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCNESBY
utterances.sentences: --and we're open-minded. But the fact of the matter is, is when you let 4,000 felons out on the street, they're not going back and getting jobs anywhere that it - that it really - that make any sense. They're back out doing what they did to put them in jail. And that's - and that's hurting the community.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The enemies of civilization, for sure. Thanks very much for telling us what's going on in Philadelphia. I appreciate it. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: MCNESBY
utterances.sentences: You got it, you got it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Time for Final Exam. Can you beat the experts at recalling the news of the week? How's your short-term memory? Find out after the break.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: FINAL EXAM.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, the world's going (ph) crazy, obviously. But we have a safe space for you. We call it Final Exam. It's the game where experts face-off against one another to determine who has paid the closest attention to the news this week. Our reigning champion is Fox Correspondent, Lauren Blanchard. Her challenger tonight, Congressman Sean Duffy of Wisconsin, who, defeated his own wife, also a Fox News Contributor, and our friend, last week. Lauren had the week off for training. Do you feel rested and ready?

utterances.speaker: LAUREN BLANCHARD, NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: I hope it's going to give me an advantage. But this is like two returning champs.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I know. This is making me nervous. So, you know the rules, obviously. But I'm going to restate them because those are the rules. Hands on buzzers. I ask the questions. First one to buzz in answers the question. You must wait until I finish asking the question before you answer it. You can answer once I acknowledge you by saying your name. Every correct answer gets you one point. Lose a question, and a point is detracted from your total. Best of five wins. Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Let's do it.

utterances.speaker: REP. SEAN PATRICK DUFFY, R-WIS.
utterances.sentences: You bought (ph) a ring on it, Tucker. I'm ready. Let's go.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: These are tough. These are really, really tough.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: All right (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I didn't even know the answers. I never do. Question one. This is a multiple choice question.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Amazon's newest delivery system is a four-wheeled robot that will bring your package right to your door because that's what America needs. What is the robot's name? Is it A, Rover, B, Wheelie, or C, Scout?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lauren Blanchard.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It's Scout.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: How would you know that?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It's a little blue box that just wheels around.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Let's see if you're right. Is it Scout?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: That's right (ph).

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: AMAZON SCOUT.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I read the article and I didn't remember the name.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Amazon will use robots to deliver packages in the suburbs of Seattle. It's the (ph) size of a cooler.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: God (ph).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They roll along sidewalks at a walking pace. They're designed to navigate around people and pets.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Scout.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: There would have to be one of those that just stayed around me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's unbelievable. And, by the way, it looks better than a clay pigeon. I bet 12-gauge sales (ph) will - will spike after that thing hits the street. Sorry, thought experiment. OK. Question two. If you thought life couldn't get better than it is now, you are wrong. Which fast food chain is now selling a scented candle that'll make your whole house smell like gravy?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lauren Blanchard.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It's KFC. They had the Yule Log. Now they have the Gravy Candle.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The thing about your answers is they're very definitive. And I don't know if that's opposed (ph) or not. Is she right? Is it KFC?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Do you want to see capitalism at work? KFC announcing a limited release Gravy-scented candle, to fill your home with that "Incredible aroma of KFC gravy."

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes, nope. Never getting that (ph).

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Are you - did you prep for this?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I have studied--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't know if the KFC company will (ph)--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: --very hard all week.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's I mean how could you study for this test?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I read a lot of news.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I guess she's doing (ph).

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: And prep for your show. I had no idea.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. So, this is a very tough one, OK?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, we'll see if you know and this again--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Is this - is this multiple choice? You tell us beforehand.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: This is - this is multiple choice.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK. Just waiting for the multiple choice, that's fast (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: This is multiple choice.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Multiple choice (ph). OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, that's a - that's a fair point. This is multiple choice. And this is another mandate from the National Game Show Commission. We have to have an animal question, so here it is this week's. The craziest video of this week shows an angry animal chasing a group of snowboarders down a mountain in Colorado. What kind of animal was it? Was it A, a moose, B, a mountain lion, C, a black bear?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Congressman Duffy.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: It would be a moose, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It was a moose.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: A moose?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well I would have guessed a mountain lion.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: A moose on the loose.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Moose.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is it a moose.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: A moose is on the loose and charges at skiers and snowboarders.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Look at this video, wild video--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: That's terrifying.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: --showing the giant animal chasing the group in Aspen, Colorado. They say it followed them for half a mile.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Moose was terrifying (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And it's too (ph)--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: There we go (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --actually, they are the most dangerous. They will kill your dog, by the way.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Mm?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They read dogs as wolves, yes.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Keep your dog away from moose.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: But they're (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Question four, this is a tough one.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: There was a rare cosmic, literally cosmic, not marijuana-related, but cosmic, as in sky, event, a few nights ago. It was seen around the world. A Super Moon passed through the Earth's shadow during a total lunar eclipse, dude (ph). It turned it a deep red. What was the name of this cosmic event?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lauren Blanchard.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It is a Super Blood Wolf Moon. Doesn't that sound intense?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Are you kidding me? Well is that--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --like a double rainbow. Probably a little bit (ph).

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It was - people were freaking out.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Was it - it was a Super Wolf--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Super Blood Wolf Moon.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Super Blood Wolf Moon, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: SANDRA SMITH, HOST
utterances.sentences: Incredible images of last night's total lunar eclipse known as the Super Blood Wolf Moon. The rare cosmic event happened at the same time as a Super Moon--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Are you kidding me?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Who thinks this up (ph)?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: --sunlight passing through

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: This is - this is not fair (ph).

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: --the earth's atmosphere turned the moon a rusty brick red.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: That's good (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You - you think if the Astronomy community has kind of stayed in Germanic but actually they're pretty groovy.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Wolf Moon, yes (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's a Wolf Moon.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Who wrote that (ph)?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right, final question.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: All right, last (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're going to wrap things up with one more multiple choice. So, wait for all the options. This is--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Is this for two points because I can't win on ones.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You know what? You could score a moral victory with this one.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And let's see if you can. If you're one of those people who can't put down your iPhone, even for a moment, you're lucky, because a new invention lets users do two things at once with a phone that is physically connected to their A, fork, B, hairdryer, C, coffee cup.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lauren Blanchard.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It's a - it's a spoon and a fork. You can put it onto the case and scoop and eat.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're like - I don't know if you're reading the questions or not.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It's a - a spoon and a fork--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is that - is that true? What is the answer?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: --that pins on the (ph) phone case.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: A new phone case comes with spoon and fork attachments.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I did it. I did it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I like that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So, you--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes, Millennials, man, we know about this stuff.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: --you don't have - have to go hunting for a spoon or a fork while you're busy--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I mean come on (ph).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: --tweeting or browsing.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: No (ph), I would never - never do that (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Congressman, I still think you're the smartest Member of Congress.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: If I had a tail, it'd be good (ph). Now, and I want to go back to here (ph). You are awesome.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, no, but, you know, you - you don't - you don't need to feel ashamed.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I am - I am not worthy.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Thank you (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: If you get flattened by this 18-wheeler (ph), you don't need to be embarrassed because I would be too. There's no chance I can--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I can win.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Awesome yes (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Still the smartest in Congress. You're a star.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Thank you (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And here's another Erik Wemple mug for you.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Drink your coffee--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I will.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --with joy.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: It doesn't say much for Congress.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Very good. That's it. Thank you both.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Thank you (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's it for this week's Final Exam. Pay close attention, Lauren Blanchard-level attention to the news this week. Tune in next Thursday to see if you could beat our experts. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: First they came for your plastic bags. Then they came for your plastic straws. Sense a theme here? If it's an organic polymer, and it makes your life easier, California is against it. Latest example, the City of Berkeley is targeting single-use plastic and paper cups, having solved every other problem in town. The City Council there just passed an ordinance that will require all businesses to charge customers 25 cents for the privilege of using a disposable cup. Greg Gutfeld uses disposable cups. He also hosts The Greg Gutfeld Show, which is excellent, and co-hosts The Five, of course, every night. He joins us tonight. So Greg, this signifies, laws like this, the - the victory over the more prosaic problems that most cities face, like bad roads or crappy schools, like obviously Berkeley has already fixed those.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. And, you know, and - and I love how this - they always do the same thing. They never, you know, try to figure out who this might help or hurt because who uses paper cups? Generally working classes that are going to get a cup of coffee--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: --on the street. They never examine the consequences of their actions because then none of their actions would be adopted because they're so terrible. There's no proof that this theft, which it is, theft, will help the planet. It's like, if you look at recycling, for example, none of the - most of the recycling, we've been separating them in bins. Now we find out that most of those bins just end up in landfill because nobody's actually buying it. Think about all that time that could have been better spent drinking. Instead, we're sitting there spreading this stuff out all over the place in the kitchen. I absolutely hate it. I am for recycling, as you know. If you watch The Five, you hear a lot of my talking points over and over again, but that's economical.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's economical. Recycling is expensive, and it doesn't contribute to a better planet, neither does taxing the working class, so it could be - so it can make you feel better. Again, this is another virtue-signal, Tucker, you know, a virtue - it's a symbolic action that does no good.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But isn't it also incredibly frivolous? I mean if you had a child, and I think our leaders should care about us, as we care about our children, if you had a child who is addicted to drugs, and failing out of school, and pregnant in the seventh grade, would you say, you know, the real problem is, "I don't like the shoelaces you have on."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I mean we--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wouldn't that kind of be missing the point?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: These are easy things to tackle. There's - there's a weird inclination among politicians these days to ban things.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like if - if they actually mistake banning for productive action when, in fact, it just limits more freedom, if people, you know, the look - let's look at the plastic straws. Did they think about what that did to the disabled? The disabled need plastic straws. And - and they didn't think about that because, you know, they thought, "Oh, it's polluting." There's an interesting fact. Do you know that 95 percent of all the plastic waste in the oceans comes from 10 rivers, eight are in Asia, two are in Africa? America is not the offender in polluting these oceans. It's other countries. Yet, we are doing this. And we're actually harming a segment of the society that needs these plastic products. There, I actually gave you some hard news.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well you did, and I'm trying to digest it now. But if that's true, and I'm obviously taking your claims on faith here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I made it up.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't have the Google machine in front of me but why wouldn't we be saying something to the countries that are actually polluting the environment?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why wouldn't we be mad about that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because that's no fun. It's no fun, Tucker. We have to be in the - in this - in this Left-wing universe, especially in the media, we are the oppressors, no matter what.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, it's like it's - it's we are at fault. We have to pay these indulgences. When you find out that it's China or the Philippines, even Brazil is - is more of a pollutant of plastics in the ocean than we are, then it's no use. You can't use it politically against the United States.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right. You went all (ph)--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So why bother?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, it goes back to the root cause which is self-hatred.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't hate myself. I'd like to opt out of this system.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I - you know, I hate you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Maybe we can someday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I hate you enough for you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do, I do.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You do. You got - you got us both covered. Greg Gutfeld, great to see you tonight. Thank you for that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I wish I could say that to you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So more tech news, Twitter, today, briefly shutdown a popular parody account. It was called Beto's Blog. It consisted of fake diary entries from the Democratic front-runner, Robert Beto O'Rourke. Now, we don't know if Beto complained to Twitter about the account. But, if so, we can see why he did. The entries were spine-tinglingly embarrassing, the kind of crap you wrote in a spiral notebook freshman year after breaking up with your high school girlfriend, and discovering marijuana. Pretty amusing! Here's a selection from them. "Have been stuck lately. In and out of a funk. My last day of work was January 2nd. It's been more than 20 years since I was last not working. Maybe if I get moving, on the road, meet people, learn what's going on, where they live, have some adventure, go where I don't know and I'm not known, I'll clear my head, reset, I'll think new thoughts, break out of the loops I've been stuck in." By the way, no periods in that sentence, just commas. Or this, "Drove to Dalhart. Ate at the Grill. Was last there in August of 2017. Green Chile cheeseburger. The table over asked if I was Beto." Or this, my favorite, "Found some crab claws. Maybe left by a bird. Walked out on a pier. Looked out, took some pictures. Leaned over, scooped up water and washed my face. Picked up beer cans that someone had left," and so on like that. Hilarious stuff! But you can see why Beto wanted it sup - oh, wait, no so (ph) we totally screwed that up. Those are actual quotes from Beto's real online diary. In other words, we couldn't make it up, but the Twitter feed was funny too. That's it for us tonight. We'll be back tomorrow night, 8 P.M., the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness, and groupthink. We have a surprise for you tonight, one night only, 9 P.M., Sean Hannity live from New York is next. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
